snippet: Spain appears poised to seek help for its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment of the depth of its economic crisis. The only questions might be when, and how much.
abstract: Spain appears poised to seek a bailout for its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment of the depth of its economic crisis; Spanish leaders say they will defer a request until they have assessed the banking sector's needs, which could be as much as $100 billion euros; European leaders are said to prefer an immediate bailout in order to prevent banking problems from swamping the entire Spanish economy.

byline.original: By RAPHAEL MINDER and PAUL GEITNER
byline.contributor: Raphael Minder reported from Madrid and Paul Geitner from Brussels. David Jolly contributed reporting from Paris and Nicholas Kulish from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: Spain appears poised to seek help for its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment of the depth of its economic crisis. The only questions might be when, and how much.

headline.main: Pressed to Take Bailout, Spain Tries to Measure Its Need
headline.print_headline: Pressed to Seek a Bailout, Spain Assesses the Needs of Its Banks
